title: E93-1066

sentences.text: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures .
The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words .
Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented .
Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words .
Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics .
Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs .
The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

Entity-turkish_word_structure.label: Turkish word structures
Entity-turkish_word_structure.description: Turkish word structures refer to the morphological configurations in the Turkish language, characterized by the agglutinative formation of words through the addition of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words, as described in a two-level morphological framework.

Entity-this_poster_paper.label: This poster paper
Entity-this_poster_paper.description: This poster paper presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of Turkish word structures, utilizing the PC-KIMMO environment and a lexicon of approximately 23,000 root words.

Entity-morphological_construction.label: morphological constructions
Entity-morphological_construction.description: Morphological constructions refer to the various surface realizations of word structures in a language, particularly in Turkish, which are formed through the application of morphological rules and are influenced by phonetic constraints such as vowel harmony.

Entity-23000_root_word.label: 23,000 roots words
Entity-23000_root_word.description: The term '23,000 roots words' refers to a comprehensive lexicon of root words utilized in the morphological analysis of Turkish language structures, serving as the foundational element for generating various word forms through affixation.

Entity-complex.label: complex
Entity-complex.description: The term 'complex' in this context refers to the intricate and multifaceted nature of Turkish morphotactics, which involves the rules and structures governing the formation and modification of words through affixation in the Turkish language.

Entity-verbal_structure.label: verbal structure
Entity-verbal_structure.description: The term 'verbal structure' refers to a morphological construct in Turkish that is formed by the addition of morphemes to a root word or stem, allowing for the conversion of a nominal form into a verbal form.

Entity-karttunen__1983.label: Karttunen, 1983
Entity-karttunen__1983.description: Karttunen, 1983 refers to a foundational work by Lauri Karttunen that presents a two-level morphological description framework, which is utilized in the analysis of Turkish word structures in the context of computational morphology.

Entity-root_word_lexicon.label: root word lexicon
Entity-root_word_lexicon.description: The 'root word lexicon' refers to a comprehensive collection of approximately 23,000 root words used as the foundational element for morphological analysis in the Turkish language, facilitating the application of phonological and morphological rules in word structure formation.

Entity-koskenniemi__1983.label: Koskenniemi, 1983
Entity-koskenniemi__1983.description: Koskenniemi, 1983 refers to a foundational work by Finnish linguist Lauri Koskenniemi that presents a two-level morphological description framework, which is utilized in the analysis of Turkish word structures in the context of computational morphology.

Entity-full_scale_two-level_morphologica.label: full scale two-level morphological description
Entity-full_scale_two-level_morphologica.description: A full scale two-level morphological description is a comprehensive framework for analyzing the morphological structure of Turkish, utilizing a root word lexicon and accounting for complex morphotactics and phonological rules.

Entity-surface_realization_of_morphologi.label: surface realizations of morphological constructions
aliases: The surface realizations of morphological constructions
Entity-surface_realization_of_morphologi.description: The surface realizations of morphological constructions refer to the actual forms that morphological structures take in a language, specifically how they are influenced and altered by phonetic rules like vowel harmony in the context of Turkish word formation.

mentions.local_name: The surface realizations of morphological constructions

Entity-derivational_and_inflectional_suf.label: derivational and inflectional suffixes
Entity-derivational_and_inflectional_suf.description: Derivational and inflectional suffixes are morphological elements that are added to root words in Turkish to create new words or modify their grammatical properties, thereby facilitating the formation of various word structures in an agglutinative language.

Entity-stem.label: stem
Entity-stem.description: In the context of Turkish morphology, 'stem' refers to the base form of a word to which morphemes can be added to create different grammatical structures, such as converting nominal forms to verbal forms.

Entity-pc-kimmo_environment.label: PC-KIMMO environment
Entity-pc-kimmo_environment.description: The PC-KIMMO environment is a software tool designed for implementing two-level morphological descriptions, particularly used for analyzing and processing the complex morphological structures of languages like Turkish.

Entity-word.label: word
Entity-word.description: The term 'word' refers to a fundamental linguistic unit in Turkish that can undergo morphological transformations through the addition of morphemes, allowing it to change its grammatical category or function.

Entity-karttunen.label: Karttunen
Entity-karttunen.description: Karttunen refers to a researcher who contributed to the development of a two-level morphological description of Turkish word structures, as cited in the paper.

Entity-antworth__1990.label: Antworth, 1990
Entity-antworth__1990.description: Antworth, 1990 refers to the implementation of the PC-KIMMO environment, which is used for morphological analysis in the study of Turkish word structures.

Entity-1990.description: The mention '1990' refers to the year in which the PC-KIMMO environment, used for implementing a morphological description of Turkish word structures, was discussed by Antworth.

Entity-agglutinative_language.label: agglutinative language
Entity-agglutinative_language.description: An agglutinative language is a type of language in which words are formed by stringing together various morphemes, typically through the addition of prefixes and suffixes, resulting in a clear and systematic structure of affixed elements.

Entity-special_case.label: special cases
Entity-special_case.description: The term 'special cases' refers to the specific instances and exceptions in the phonological and morphological rules of the Turkish language that have been accounted for in the morphological description presented in the paper.

Entity-morphological_rule.label: morphological rules
Entity-morphological_rule.description: Morphological rules are systematic guidelines in linguistics that govern the structure and formation of words through the arrangement and modification of morphemes.

Entity-nominal.label: nominal
Entity-nominal.description: In the context of Turkish morphology, 'nominal' refers to a grammatical category that encompasses words functioning as nouns or noun-like entities, which can be transformed into verbal structures through morphological processes.

Entity-exception.label: exceptions
Entity-exception.description: In the context of Turkish morphology, 'exceptions' refers to the special cases that deviate from the established phonological and morphological rules within the language's complex structure.

Entity-morphotactics.label: morphotactics
Entity-morphotactics.description: Morphotactics is a linguistic concept that refers to the rules governing the structure and arrangement of morphemes within words in a given language.

Entity-affixation.label: affixations
Entity-affixation.description: Affixations are linguistic processes that involve the addition of prefixes, suffixes, or infixes to root words to create new words or modify their grammatical function.

Entity-morphological_description.label: morphological description
Entity-morphological_description.description: A morphological description is a systematic representation of the structure and formation of words in a language, detailing the rules and patterns of morphology.

Entity-antworth.label: Antworth
Entity-antworth.description: Antworth refers to a researcher and author who implemented the PC-KIMMO environment for morphological analysis in Turkish, as cited in the paper from 1990.

Entity-root_word.label: root words
Entity-root_word.description: Root words are the fundamental units of meaning in a language from which other words can be derived through the addition of prefixes, suffixes, or other modifications.

Entity-inflectional_suffix.label: inflectional suffixes
Entity-inflectional_suffix.description: Inflectional suffixes are morphemes added to the end of root words to indicate grammatical features such as tense, mood, number, or case in a language.

Entity-turkish.label: Turkish
Entity-turkish.description: Turkish refers to anything related to Turkey, including its people, culture, and the Turkish language, which is a member of the Turkic language family.

Entity-pc-kimmo.label: PC-KIMMO
Entity-pc-kimmo.description: PC-KIMMO is a computational tool and software environment designed for morphological analysis and generation in linguistics.

Entity-phonetic_rule.label: phonetic rules
Entity-phonetic_rule.description: Phonetic rules are systematic guidelines in linguistics that govern how sounds are produced and perceived in spoken language, often influencing the pronunciation of words based on their phonetic environment.

Entity-morpheme.label: morphemes
Entity-morpheme.description: Morphemes are the smallest units of meaning in a language that can be combined to form words and convey grammatical relationships.

Entity-finite-state.label: finite-state
Entity-finite-state.description: Finite-state refers to a computational model used in automata theory and formal language theory, which represents a system with a limited number of states and transitions between those states, often applied in various fields such as linguistics, computer science, and natural language processing.

Entity-koskenniemi.label: Koskenniemi
Entity-koskenniemi.description: Koskenniemi refers to a researcher and author known for contributions to morphological analysis in linguistics.

Entity-vowel_harmony.label: vowel harmony
Entity-vowel_harmony.description: Vowel harmony is a phonological phenomenon in which vowels within a word harmonize to share certain features, such as frontness or backness, affecting the pronunciation and structure of the word.

Entity-adverbial_construct.label: adverbial constructs
Entity-adverbial_construct.description: Adverbial constructs are linguistic elements that function to modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs, typically providing information about the manner, time, place, or degree of the action or state described.

Entity-poster_paper.label: poster paper
Entity-poster_paper.description: A poster paper is a visual presentation of research findings, typically displayed at academic conferences, summarizing key aspects of a study in a concise format.

summary: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures . The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words . Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented . Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words . Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics . Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs . The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' indicates a relationship where the subject provides an explanation, representation, or account of the object. It signifies that the subject conveys information about the characteristics, features, or details of the object, thereby enhancing the understanding of the object through the subject's perspective or analysis.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' serves to establish a relationship of belonging or association between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is characterized by, related to, or derived from the object, thereby providing a context or framework within which the subject can be understood. In general, this predicate connects entities by highlighting a specific aspect or feature that the subject possesses in relation to the object.

Predicate-has_been_implemented_using.label: has been implemented using
Predicate-has_been_implemented_using.description: The predicate 'has been implemented using' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object, indicating that the subject is realized or constructed through the application of the methods, tools, or frameworks represented by the object. This implies that the object serves as a foundational or instrumental component in the development or execution of the subject.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' establishes a foundational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject derives its principles, structure, or functionality from the object. It suggests that the object serves as a source, reference, or underlying framework that informs or supports the subject's existence or operation.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject encompasses or includes the object as a part of its entirety. It establishes a relationship where the subject is a larger entity that holds or possesses the object, which represents a specific quantity, element, or component that is integral to the subject.

Predicate-are_exceptions_to.label: are exceptions to
Predicate-are_exceptions_to.description: The predicate 'are exceptions to' indicates that the subject does not conform to the general principles or norms established by the object. It signifies a deviation or a specific instance that falls outside the typical rules or classifications represented by the object, highlighting a distinction between the subject and the broader category defined by the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or inclusion between the subject and the object, where the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object. In this context, it signifies that the subject embodies certain attributes, features, or components represented by the object.

Predicate-applied_to.label: applied to
Predicate-applied_to.description: The predicate 'applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the object, suggesting that the subject acts upon or modifies the object in some manner. This connection often implies a functional or operational interaction, where the subject serves a purpose or achieves an effect concerning the object.

Predicate-added_to.label: added to
Predicate-added_to.description: The predicate 'added to' indicates a relationship where the subject is combined with or incorporated into the object, resulting in a new or modified entity. This connection implies that the subject contributes additional elements, characteristics, or functions to the object, enhancing or altering its original form or meaning.

Predicate-can_convert.label: can convert
Predicate-can_convert.description: The predicate 'can convert' indicates the ability or capacity of the subject to change or transform into the object, suggesting a process of alteration or reconfiguration that results in a different form or representation.

Predicate-can_convert_to.label: can convert to
Predicate-can_convert_to.description: The predicate 'can convert to' indicates a potential transformation or change in state from the subject to the object, suggesting that the subject possesses the capability or possibility to be altered into the form or structure represented by the object.

Predicate-can_create.label: can create
Predicate-can_create.description: The predicate 'can create' indicates the ability or capacity of the subject to produce or generate the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject possesses the skill or potential to bring forth the object, which can be a tangible or intangible entity. In this context, the subject is often a source of creativity or functionality, while the object represents the outcome or product of that creative process.

Predicate-are_constrained_and_modified_b.label: are constrained and modified by
Predicate-are_constrained_and_modified_b.description: The predicate 'are constrained and modified by' indicates a relationship where the subject is subject to limitations and alterations imposed by the object. This suggests that the characteristics, behaviors, or properties of the subject are influenced or shaped by the rules, principles, or factors represented by the object, leading to a dynamic interaction between the two entities.

Predicate-such_as.label: such as
Predicate-such_as.description: The predicate 'such as' is used to introduce examples or specific instances that illustrate or clarify the subject. It connects the subject to the object by indicating that the object is a representative example or a subset of the broader category defined by the subject.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' establishes a relationship where the subject encompasses or contains the object as a part of its broader category or framework. It indicates that the object is a component, aspect, or element that is part of the subject, suggesting a relationship of belonging or incorporation.

Predicate-presents_a_comprehensive_two-l.label: presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of
Predicate-presents_a_comprehensive_two-l.description: The predicate 'presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of' indicates that the subject is providing an in-depth examination or study that focuses on the morphological aspects of the object. This analysis is structured at two distinct levels, suggesting a detailed exploration of both the surface and underlying forms of the linguistic elements within the object, which in this context refers to a specific linguistic phenomenon or structure.

Predicate-are_surface_realizations_of.label: are surface realizations of
Predicate-are_surface_realizations_of.description: The predicate 'are surface realizations of' establishes a relationship where the subject represents tangible or observable forms that manifest or express the underlying concepts or structures denoted by the object. In this context, the subject can be seen as the concrete examples or instances that illustrate the abstract principles or frameworks described by the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or concept that falls under the wider category or concept represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a broader scope or definition that includes the subject, thereby situating the subject within a larger framework of understanding.
